thread.title: Catholic heritage sites in pope host cities: NYC, DC, Philly
thread.title_full: Catholic heritage sites in pope host cities: NYC, DC, Philly

author: BETH J. HARPAZ The Associated Press
title: Catholic heritage sites in pope host cities: NYC, DC, Philly
text:
Catholic heritage sites in pope host cities: NYC, DC, Philly Associated Press | 
Pope Francis will visit three U.S. cities, Washington, New York and Philadelphia, Wednesday through next Sunday. For travelers with an interest in sacred places, here are some of the top Catholic heritage sites — including several on the pope’s itinerary — in those cities. 
Washington 
Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle, 1725 Rhode Island Ave. NW; www.stmatthewscathedral.org . Site of President John F. Kennedy’s funeral Mass; on the pope’s itinerary. 
Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception, 400 Michigan Ave. NE, www.nationalshrine.com . One of the largest churches in the world; on the pope’s itinerary. Located next to Catholic University. 
Holy Trinity Catholic Church, 3513 N St. NW, trinity.org/ . Founded in 1792 as the city’s first Catholic Church; located in Georgetown. 
St. Augustine Catholic Church, 15th and V streets NW, saintaugustine-dc.org . Founded in 1858 by emancipated black Catholics. 
Franciscan Monastery, 1400 Quincy St. NE, www.myfranciscan.org . Shrines, catacombs and gardens. Tours offered daily. 
Saint John Paul II National Shrine, 3900 Harewood Road NE, www.jp2shrine.org . Relics, exhibit, services. 
New York 
St. Patrick’s Cathedral, Fifth Avenue between 50th and 51st streets, near Rockefeller Center, www.saintpatrickscathedral.org . Seat of the New York Archdiocese. Bronze doors bear carved images of New Yorkers who have been canonized; on the pope’s itinerary. 
The Basilica of St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral, Mott and Prince streets, www.oldsaintpatricks.com . Cathedral opened 1815. 
St. Peter’s Church, Barclay and Church streets, spcolr.org . Located a block from the World Trade Center. The church was damaged on Sept. 11, 2001. The parish dates to the 1700s. 
St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Shrine in Our Lady of the Rosary Church, 7 State St., near the Staten Island Ferry terminal. Seton was the first U.S.-born saint. 
St. Frances Cabrini Shrine, 701 Fort Washington Ave., near 190th Street in Washington Heights, www.cabrinishrinenyc.org . The shrine honors Frances Xavier Cabrini, an Italian immigrant considered patroness of immigrants. 
The Cloisters, in Fort Tryon Park, Washington Heights, www.metmuseum.org/visit/visit-the-cloisters . Museum assembled from portions of Medieval European cloisters, owned by the Metropolitan Museum. Stained glass windows and tapestries. 
Billboard: Not a sacred spot, but a 225-foot portrait of the pope adorns a building at Eighth Avenue and 34th Street, near Madison Square Garden, where the pope is scheduled to celebrate Mass. 
Philadelphia 
Cathedral Basilica of Saints Peter and Paul, 18th Street and Benjamin Franklin Parkway, www.cathedralphila.org . Knotted Grotto outside the basilica, dedicated to Mary, Undoer of Knots. Seat of the Philadelphia archdiocese; on the pope’s itinerary. 
National Shrine of St. John Neumann, 1019 N. Fifth St., www.stjohnneumann.org . The shrine honors the 18th-century Philadelphia bishop credited with expanding the U.S. Catholic education system. 
National Shrine of St. Rita of Cascia, 1166 S. Broad St., www.saintritashrine.org . The shrine began as a parish church dedicated to St. Rita — known as “saint of the impossible” and the “peacemaker” — to help welcome Italian immigrants. 
Central Association of the Miraculous Medal, 475 E. Chelten Ave., cammonline.org/ . Dedicated to Mary. Stained glass and sculpture. 
Old St. Joseph’s Roman Catholic Church, 321 Willings Alley, www.oldstjoseph.org . Philadelphia’s oldest Catholic community, founded and staffed by Jesuits. 
Old St. Mary’s Church, 252 S. Fourth St., www.oldstmary.com . Built in 1763. Site of the first public religious commemoration of the Declaration of Independence; visited by George Washington and John Adams. 
Elsewhere in Pennsylvania: 
St. Katharine Drexel Shrine, 1663 Bristol Pike, Bensalem, www.katharinedrexel.org . The shrine honors an heiress who spent her fortune improving the lives of African-Americans and Native Americans. 
National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa, 654 Ferry Road, Doylestown, www.czestochowa.us . Polish-American Roman Catholic shrine; houses reproduction of Black Madonna icon of Czestochowa, Poland. 
St. Charles Borromeo Seminary, 100 E. Wynnewood Road, Wynnewood, www.scs.edu . Founded in 1832. On the pope’s itinerary. (Not open to the public the week of the pope’s visit.) 
Associated Press writer Natalie Pompilio contributed to this story.
